title: Unilateral Acoustic Trauma with Tinnitus and Hyperacusis
chief_complaint: I heard a loud 'pop' in my left ear after shooting a pistol five months ago, and immediately lost hearing. Since then, I have constant high-pitched ringing, a feeling of fullness, and sensitivity to loud sounds in that ear.

problem_summary.onset: Sudden onset 5 months prior to the evaluation.
problem_summary.course: Stable; no improvement after a course of oral steroids taken 2 months post-incident.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Aural fullness, tinnitus (high-pitched, constant, distracting), and hyperacusis.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Difficulty understanding speech in groups and various communication situations; tinnitus is extremely distracting.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Seeking evaluation and management for hearing loss and bothersome symptoms.

history.present_illness: The patient experienced sudden hearing deterioration, aural fullness, tinnitus, and hyperacusis in the left ear immediately after shooting a pistol. She describes hearing a 'pop' during the event. She sought treatment 2 months later and completed a course of oral steroids with no improvement.
history.otologic_history: No reported history of ear pathology or otosurgery.
history.noise_exposure_history: Specific incident of acoustic trauma (pistol shot). No other significant noise exposure reported.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear shows normal sensitivity through 4000 Hz with a slight slope to mild loss at 6-8 kHz. Left ear shows a mild sensorineural loss in low frequencies (250-1500 Hz), recovering slightly at 2000 Hz, then sloping to a moderate loss at 3000-4000 Hz, and recovering to mild loss at 6000-8000 Hz.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear has excellent speech recognition. Left ear shows reduced word recognition ability consistent with cochlear damage.

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear normal (Type A). Left ear hypercompliant (Type Ad).

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.key_findings: Normal acoustic reflex thresholds at 500 through 4000 Hz with ipsilateral and contralateral stimulation, despite the hypercompliant tympanogram in the left ear.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with a unilateral, irregular sensorineural hearing loss in the left ear, characterized by mild low-frequency loss and a moderate notch at 3-4 kHz, consistent with acoustic trauma. Word recognition in the left ear is reduced (72%), indicating moderate difficulty. The left tympanic membrane is hypercompliant (Type Ad) but acoustic reflexes remain intact.
counseling_points: Explain that the 'pop' and subsequent hearing loss were likely caused by the high-intensity impulse noise from the pistol, damaging the inner ear structures.
Discuss that while the steroid treatment was appropriate, the delay in administration may have limited its effectiveness, and the current hearing levels are likely permanent.
Recommend a hearing aid evaluation for the left ear to improve communication in groups and help mask the tinnitus.
Advise on the use of Hearing Assistive Technology (HAT) if hearing aids alone are insufficient in noise.
Counsel on tinnitus management strategies and hyperacusis desensitization.
Emphasize the critical importance of wearing hearing protection (earplugs/muffs) during any future exposure to loud noise to preserve remaining hearing.
notes_for_actor: Portray the tinnitus as very distressing; it is a constant high-pitched ring that makes it hard to concentrate.
Mention that loud sounds (hyperacusis) are physically uncomfortable in the left ear.
You are frustrated that the medication didn't help and that the symptoms have persisted for 5 months.
